awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Synthesis Methods to Control Framework Aluminum Distribution in Zeolites for NOx Pollution Abatement Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract (Gounder; 1552517)
This study will develop new synthesis strategies to control the distribution of aluminum (Al) active sites in zeolite catalysts used for nitrogen oxides (NOx) abatement and carbon feedstock conversion to fuels and chemicals.  Tailoring active site proximity and distribution in zeolites will open new opportunities for catalytic innovation in both the environmental protection and carbon conversion areas, while also providing new insight into the chemistry of zeolite crystallization.  The research will be linked with educational and mentoring initiatives in the STEM areas for students at all levels.

Currently, there is little understanding of the relationships between the atomic arrangement of Al atoms in zeolites and the chemistry of the precursor solutions and gels used to synthesize them.  This work is based on the hypothesis that the distribution of catalytically-relevant isolated and paired Al sites in zeolites can be controlled by the charge density of the synthesis gel.  Isolated and paired Al sites have been shown by the principal investigator to play important roles in the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx using copper (Cu)-exchanged chabazite zeolites.  The present study will develop predictive relations between synthesis gel charge density and paired Al density for a range of zeolites, establish relationships between the framework Al distribution and extraframework Cu distribution in Cu-zeolites, and determine their kinetic and mechanistic roles in the NOx SCR reaction.  Building on prior collaborative research, the PI will utilize characterization tools that provide rapid quantification of the numbers of total and paired acid sites on proton- and metal-exchanged zeolites, thereby facilitating the development of synthesis-structure-function relationships that can be used to tailor zeolites for a range of applications.

por.por_cntn:
Zeolites are an important class of catalysts ubiquitous in the global petrochemical and refining industries, chemical manufacturing, and emissions control. Copper-exchanged zeolites are used commercially in diesel engine exhaust aftertreatment for the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxides (NOx), which are pollutants and greenhouse gases that negatively impact environmental and human health. The catalytic performance of zeolite materials depends not only on their macroscopic properties such as bulk structure and composition, but also on their microscopic properties such as the atomic arrangements of aluminum (Al) substituted into their silica-based frameworks and of copper (Cu) ions exchanged at extra-framework locations. However, zeolites typically contain wide variations in the atomic arrangements of their active sites, because these material properties are not well controlled in current catalyst synthesis routes. Understanding how zeolite crystallization influences the atomic scale Al arrangement will enable developing Cu-zeolites with improved NOx conversion at low temperatures to more effectively mitigate NOx pollution, enabling meeting more stringent emissions standards in the future and developing more efficient combustion engines that reduce CO2 emissions and fuel consumption, which will benefit society.

 

By combining state-of-the-art approaches in experimental synthesis, characterization and catalysis research, this project developed new strategies to control the distribution of Al and Cu active sites in zeolite catalysts. The technical strategy was to use mixtures of organic and inorganic structure-directing agent (SDA) cations to influence the siting of Al atoms in zeolite frameworks during crystallization. This led to the development of predictive relations between SDA structure and composition and the microscopic Al arrangements formed in zeolites, for a range of SDA molecules and zeolite frameworks. This project also developed experimental spectroscopic and titration protocols to identify and quantify different Al-Al site pair ensembles in zeolites. These data facilitated the development of synthesis-structure-function relations that allow designing new zeolite synthesis approaches to tailor active site arrangements. Kinetic and mechanistic models were developed to explain how Cu site density influenced NOx SCR reaction performance in Cu-form zeolites, and how acid site density influenced methanol dehydration reaction performance in H-form zeolites. Studying the details of these reaction mechanisms identified features of NOx SCR and methanol conversion catalyst performance, such as the active site arrangements that accelerate the rates of elementary steps that limit conversion at low temperatures (<200 oC), which are important to understand to develop more efficient catalysts in real-world applications.

 

This project has had significant broader impacts in the scientific community so as to educate and inform the public. In particular, new experimental tools were developed to synthesize and characterize zeolite catalysts of different microscopic distributions of active sites. Such an approach is needed to truly understand how and why zeolite catalysts work, which can be applied more broadly in studies of other chemical reactions and of other porous catalyst materials. This project has trained 7 graduate students, 9 undergraduate students, and 1 high school student, in communicating their findings and working effectively in trans-disciplinary collaborative research teams. Outreach activities and demonstrations were developed to educate K-12 students about how catalysis impacts their daily lives, and how emissions catalysis is important to protect the environment and human health, and these results were disseminated in science education journals for other educators to implement the demonstrations in their local communities. During this project period, these activities were offered to >300 K-12 students in outreach programs targeted to recruiting underrepresented students into the STEM disciplines.
